title: Authenticated XXE
vulnerability_information:
## Description:

The WordPress core Media Library does not securely parse XML content when running on PHP 8. By uploading a malicious .wav file, an authenticated attacker can trigger a XXE vulnerability which enables to read secret system files, DoS the web server, perform SSRF, or aim at Remote Code Execution via Phar Deserialization.

## Steps To Reproduce:

Requirements:
* latest WordPress 5.6 installation
* running on PHP 8
* *author* user privileges in WordPress, or higher
* another web server that is controlled by the attacker to retrieve leaked data

The vulnerability can be exploited by uploading a crafted .wav file. The attached archive contains such a .wav file with a payload for extracting the content of */etc/passwd* by loading an external DTD. To reproduce:

1. Adapt the address in the 2 files in the attached PoC archive to point to a web server that you control (and that is reachable from the targeted WordPress installation).
2. For the .wav file, the address has to be adapted at `0x000338CD` (best use a hex editor for this, doing that with a text editor might corrupt the file).
3. Put the file *xxe.dtd* at the root of the webserver that you control.
4. Login to WordPress as author and upload *xxe.wav*  in the media library.
5. The content of */etc/passwd* will appear in the access logs of the web server base64 encoded (see attached screenshot).

## Vulnerable Code:

The vulnerable code commit is the following:
https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/commit/03eba7beb2f5b96bd341255eaa30d6b612e62507

The vulnerable code is:
```
			if (PHP_VERSION_ID < 80000) {
				// http://websec.io/2012/08/27/Preventing-XEE-in-PHP.html
				// https://core.trac.wordpress.org/changeset/29378
				// This function has been deprecated in PHP 8.0 because in libxml 2.9.0, external entity loading is
				// disabled by default, so this function is no longer needed to protect against XXE attacks.
				$loader = libxml_disable_entity_loader(true);
			}
			$XMLobject = simplexml_load_string($XMLstring, 'SimpleXMLElement', LIBXML_NOENT);
```

It was recently modified to accommodate for the deprecation of the `libxml_disable_entity_loader()` function in PHP 8. The mistake here is to rely on the fact that XXE is no longer possible by default in PHP 8 (as it requires libxml version > 2.9). This is true, but using the `LIBXML_NOENT` flag is certainly not the default. The flag explicitly activates entity substitution (the name of the flag might be a little misleading). So if user input reaches that point as part of the `$XMLstring` variable, XXE is possible.

## Impact

An attacker can:
- read secret system files, such as *.htaccess* or *wp-config.php*
- DoS the web server via a malicious XML document, or by loading */dev/urandom* via XXE
- fingerprint and exploit services in the internal network by turning the XXE into SSRF
- trigger a Phar Deserialization by using the `phar://` stream wrapper within the XXE which can lead to further vulnerabilities, depending on the gadget chains available in the WordPress core and its plugins.

activities.message:
Hi @sonarsourceresearch,

Thanks for the report! Just acknowledging the receipt for now - will get back to you once we've reviewed it. This may take a few days.

Cheers

Hello ehtis,

please note that at SonarSource we are following a 90 days disclosure deadline. After 90 days elapse, parts of the bug report will become visible to the public. We do not release exploit code and focus on learnings for other (PHP8) developers.

Please let us know if we can help and we are happy to hear about updates.

Best

Hi @sonarsource,

An update: We're actively working on a fix. A patch is being reviewed and we'll work to include it in a release as soon as possible.

I understand you're on a 90 days disclosure deadline. We're trying to get it fixed within this window, but in case things take an unexpected turn, we would very much welcome your cooperation in this regard.

Will keep you updated.

Thank you!

Hi @sonarsource,

As you might already know, our security updates are done in point releases (security/maintenance releases) and not major version updates, so we're now targeting this fix for the upcoming security release, that's going to be 5.7.1.

The next major update will be 5.7.0, but as this fix will actually be a security fix, so it won't be included in that. Rather, the latest security release (5.7.1) will have it, and we expedited our efforts to get a patch ready for this reason

Thanks!

Hello ehtis,

thank you for your status update, makes sense. And kudos for the fast progress on this!

Best

Hello, 

This will be included in the WordPress 5.7.1 release scheduled for late 2300 UTC Wednesday April 14. How would you like to be credited?

I've got the following in the release post draft but will update it if I hear back from you.

> Thank you [SonarSource](https://www.sonarsource.com/) for reporting an XXE vulnerability within the media library affecting PHP 8

Many thanks,
Peter

Hi @ehtis, @peterwilsoncc,

As WordPress 5.7.1 was released as planned (good job!), can we proceed and disclose this report?

Thanks!

Hi @sonarsource,

Sure - generally, disclosure is available 30 days after the fix. So, let's do it on ~May 14th.

Cheers
Hi! Can we proceed with the disclosure? Thanks!
Hi @ehtis, it appears that this submission has not been rewarded, while the WordPress Core is still part of the scope eligible for monetary bounties. Can you please double check? Thanks!
@sonarsource Apologies for the delay on that, working on getting the bounty released to you.

Hi,

We would like thank you again for your submission and helping make WordPress a safer place. We look forward to more reports from you in the future.

Thank you again!
Hi, thank you for the bounty!

Hi,

Updating for the sake of completion: The bounty has been donated to https://www.inara.org/ 
We are happy to have helped harden the WordPress project.

Thank you for your work.

summaries.content: The WordPress core Media Library did not securely parse XML content when running on PHP 8. By uploading a malicious .wav file, an authenticated attacker could trigger a XXE vulnerability which enabled to read secret system files, DoS the web server, perform SSRF, or aim at Remote Code Execution via Phar Deserialization. Find the technical advisory in our blog: https://blog.sonarsource.com/wordpress-xxe-security-vulnerability.
